page.title: 07WARMINSTER'S ADVICE CENTRE
page.content: The Citizen's Advice Bureau was founded in 1939 to help people with war problems. People thought it would fade away but it is still running today, with 900 branches nationwide. The Warminster branch opened in the High Street, behind St Laurence's, in 1981. Local Organiser, Mrs Jean Swift, who is helped by 15 men and women volunteers, reports that about 15 to 20 people come for advice every day. The Bureau deals with all sorts of problems, including social security, consumer complaints, employment, housing and family problems. Staff can consult a "library" of detailed information, and obtain more help from Head Office in London. Confidentiality is guaranteed: even if the problem involves a law-breaker,the Bureau will offer advice, but not divulge clients' details without a court subpoena.
